--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jim O'Flaherty, Jr." 
<jim_oflaherty_jr@y...> wrote:
> I am concerned about your representing "presentation" information 
>with your "structure" information.  Would it not be more effective 
>to have a second XML document detailing "presentation" details, and 
>have that document "point" to the "structure" XML document?  

Well, the only two attributes of the XML that deal with presentation 
are the two "hint" attributes in the neuron tags, and as Colin 
suggested, those could simply be optional.  Include them if you want 
to graphically represent the networks...leave them out otherwise.

All other information in XML is relevant to its actual structure and 
function.

>That way, those who want to work strictly with data structure and 
>have not care for the presentation, are not burdened with the 
>presentation data.  

Just leave out the "hint" tags.

>Additionally, there will be other types of presentation that will 
>likely be created later.  I am assuming you would not want to add 
>this presentation data to this XML, right?

Not as an integral part of the XML...but if someone else wanted to 
include optional attributes to assist with graphical representation, 
that could easily be ignored when parsing...that'd be fine.

Personally, I'd prefer one basic format for network XML, with 
optional attributes, rather than keep track of two forms of XML. 

Derek
